children.value: <IntroParagraph>
The
intantness
of chat apps has always been a mystery to me.
The technical details of moving emojis through The Internet Pipes and across continents in 0.004 miliseconds is well beyond my paygrade.
</IntroParagraph>
But I got a tiny window of insight into the magic while illustrating notes for
Mark Barton's course
on building chat apps with
Vue
and
Socket.io
Turns out it's not magic, but instead done through
websockets
. Which are like little portals that hold open a consistent connection between two machines.
I obviously still haven't a clue what goes on inside that dark little portal. Thankfully using tools like Vue & Socket.io save us from that level of depth.

<BasicImage alt="Vue and socket.io for real-time communication" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/c_scale,w_800/v1592262571/maggieappleton.com/egghead-course-notes/vuesocket/vuesocket1.png" />

<BasicImage alt="Socket.io gives us bidirectional communication between two clients" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/c_scale,w_900/v1592262575/maggieappleton.com/egghead-course-notes/vuesocket/vuesocket2.png" />

<BasicImage alt="The emit method lets us send and recieve any knd of event. We can target specific users or a group of users" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/c_scale,w_900/v1592262574/maggieappleton.com/egghead-course-notes/vuesocket/vuesocket3.png" />

<BasicImage alt="The full vue and socket sketchnote" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/c_scale,w_900/v1592262568/maggieappleton.com/egghead-course-notes/vuesocket/vuesocket_sketchnotes--mini.png" />
